transcript:
Patient: Hi, I'm back for session 15. Here is the summary you provided me at the end of our last session:

- Main topics discussed:
  - Continued exploring the connection between Priya's core belief of "I'm not good enough" and their struggles with setting boundaries, particularly at work
  - Discussed a specific situation where Priya felt guilty for considering saying no to an additional project at work
  - Challenged the negative thoughts associated with setting boundaries using evidence for and against and reframed the thoughts in a more balanced way
  - Checked in on Priya's emotional state and progress with practicing CBT skills

- Techniques or exercises used:
  - Thought records: Priya is continuing to practice identifying negative automatic thoughts, emotions, and evidence against those thoughts. We will continue to build on this skill in future sessions.
  - Positive Data Log: Priya has been gathering evidence against their negative core beliefs. We will continue to review Priya's log in future sessions and use it to build more balanced beliefs.
  - Behavioral experiments: Priya tried setting a boundary with a family member as an experiment to challenge their belief "I'm not good enough." We will continue to use experiments to build new, more adaptive beliefs, particularly related to setting boundaries at work.
  - Cognitive restructuring: Continued to work on challenging negative thoughts and core beliefs using Socratic questioning and examining evidence.

- Homework assigned:
  - Continue keeping a Positive Data Log to gather evidence against negative core beliefs
  - Complete at least one thought record on a situation that comes up between now and our next session, particularly if it relates to setting boundaries at work or with family
  - Try another behavioral experiment related to setting boundaries at work, such as saying no to an extra task when feeling overwhelmed

- Patient's progress, challenges, depression symptoms and important personal details:
  - Priya is making progress in recognizing and challenging negative thoughts and core beliefs, though it remains challenging at times
  - Priya's depression symptoms, such as feelings of guilt and worthlessness, continue to be present but may be gradually improving as they practice CBT skills
  - Priya's cultural background and family relationships may continue to influence their thoughts and emotions

- Core beliefs and intermediate beliefs:
  - Core belief: "I'm not good enough"
  - Intermediate beliefs: "I should always be there for my family." "If I don't support my family perfectly, I'm a terrible sibling." "If I say no at work, my colleagues or supervisor will think I'm not a team player or capable."

- Important information to carry forward:
  - Priya's willingness to practice CBT skills and their recognition of the connection between thoughts, feelings, and behaviors are important strengths to build upon
  - Continuing to address cultural factors and family relationships will be crucial in understanding Priya's experiences and challenges
  - Tracking Priya's progress with thought records, reframing, and self-compassion will provide valuable information for future sessions

- Plan for the next session:
  - Review Priya's Positive Data Log and discuss their experience with the new behavioral experiment related to setting boundaries at work
  - Continue exploring and challenging negative core beliefs and cognitive distortions
  - Introduce additional CBT techniques, such as cognitive and behavioral experiments, depending on Priya's needs and progress

Therapist: Hello Priya, it's great to see you again for our 15th session. Before we dive in, I want to acknowledge my limitations as an AI therapist. While I can provide support and guidance based on the information you share with me, I don't have access to real-time information or personal details beyond what you provide in our sessions. There's also a potential for me to generate inaccurate information or misinterpret something you say. Additionally, I'm not equipped to provide crisis intervention or emergency services, and I can't directly observe or interpret non-verbal cues. With that said, I'm here to support you in the best way I can. How have you been since our last session?

Patient: Thanks for the reminder, Nova. I understand your limitations, and I appreciate the support you've been providing me. Since our last session, I've been trying to practice the skills we've discussed, like challenging negative thoughts and setting boundaries. It's still challenging at times, but I think I'm making some progress. I've also been keeping up with the Positive Data Log and thought records, which have been helpful in recognizing patterns in my thinking.

Therapist: It's great to hear that you've been practicing the skills we've discussed and finding them helpful. Recognizing progress, even if it feels small, is an important part of the process. Can you share a specific example of when you challenged a negative thought or set a boundary since our last session?

Patient: One example that comes to mind is when my supervisor asked me to take on an additional project at work. Normally, I would have said yes without hesitation, even if I was already overwhelmed. But this time, I took a moment to consider my workload and my own needs. I politely explained that I wouldn't be able to take on the project without compromising the quality of my other work. It was difficult, but I felt a sense of relief afterward.

Therapist: That's a great example of setting a boundary at work, Priya. It takes courage to assert your needs, especially in a professional setting. How did it feel to prioritize your own well-being in that moment?

Patient: It felt empowering, but also a bit scary. I think I'm still working on believing that it's okay to put my needs first sometimes. I noticed that my initial thoughts were along the lines of "I'm letting my team down" or "They'll think I'm not a team player." But I tried to challenge those thoughts by reminding myself that setting boundaries is actually a sign of self-respect and can lead to better work quality in the long run.

Therapist: You've made an important connection there, Priya. Challenging those negative thoughts and reframing them in a more balanced way is a key part of the process. It's natural to feel some fear or guilt when setting boundaries, especially if it's something new for you. But as you practice, it will likely become easier and more comfortable.

Given what you've shared so far, what would you like to focus on in today's session? We could explore more around setting boundaries, continue working on challenging negative thoughts, or address anything else that's been on your mind.

Patient: I think I'd like to focus on setting boundaries, both at work and with my family. It's something I struggle with, and I know it's connected to my core belief of "I'm not good enough." I'd also like to discuss how my cultural background might be influencing my thoughts and behaviors around boundary-setting.

Therapist: That sounds like a productive agenda for today's session, Priya. We can explore the connection between your core belief and boundary-setting, as well as how your cultural background might be playing a role. Setting boundaries is a skill that takes practice, so we can also discuss some strategies for asserting your needs in a way that feels authentic and respectful.

Before we dive in, let's take a moment to check in on your emotional state. How are you feeling right now, and how has your mood been in general since our last session?

Patient: Right now, I'm feeling a bit anxious about discussing boundary-setting, but also hopeful that I can make progress in this area. In general, my mood has been more stable since our last session. I've had some low moments, but I've been trying to use the skills we've discussed to cope with them. I think the thought records and Positive Data Log have been especially helpful in recognizing and challenging negative thoughts.

Therapist: It's understandable to feel some anxiety about discussing boundary-setting, especially if it's an area where you've faced challenges in the past. It's also great to hear that your mood has been more stable overall and that you've been able to use the skills we've discussed to cope with low moments. Recognizing and challenging negative thoughts is a key part of managing depression, and it sounds like you're making progress in that area.

As we explore boundary-setting today, we'll go at a pace that feels comfortable for you. Remember that it's okay to take breaks or let me know if something feels overwhelming. Our goal is to support your growth and well-being, not to push you beyond your limits.

With that in mind, let's start by discussing how your core belief of "I'm not good enough" might be connected to your struggles with setting boundaries. Can you share an example of a time when this belief influenced your ability to assert your needs?

Patient: One situation that comes to mind is when my sister asked me to help her move on a weekend when I had already made plans with some friends. My initial thought was that I had to say yes because that's what a good sibling would do. I felt guilty even considering saying no.

Therapist: That's a great example, Priya. Let's break this down using the CBT framework. The situation or trigger was your sister asking for help. The emotion you experienced was guilt, and the automatic thought was "I have to say yes because that's what a good sibling would do." Does that sound accurate?

Patient: Yes, that sums it up well.

Therapist: Now, let's explore the evidence for and against this thought. What evidence supports the idea that you have to say yes to be a good sibling?

Patient: Well, I've always been taught that family comes first and that we should be there for each other no matter what. Saying no feels like I'm not living up to that expectation.

Therapist: That's understandable given your cultural background and family values. Now, let's consider the evidence against this thought. What are some reasons why it might be okay to say no in this situation?

Patient: I guess one reason is that I had already made plans with my friends, and it's important to honor those commitments too. Another reason is that I need time for self-care and relaxation, and constantly putting others' needs before my own can lead to burnout and resentment.

Therapist: Those are valid points, Priya. It's important to find a balance between supporting your family and taking care of your own needs. Saying no doesn't mean you're a bad sibling; it means you're setting healthy boundaries and prioritizing your well-being.

Let's try reframing the original thought in a more balanced way. Instead of "I have to say yes because that's what a good sibling would do," what's an alternative thought that takes into account the evidence for and against?

Patient: I could reframe it as "I can be a good sibling while also setting boundaries and taking care of myself. Saying no in this situation doesn't negate all the other times I've been there for my family."

Therapist: That's a great reframe, Priya! It acknowledges the importance of family while also recognizing the need for self-care and boundary-setting. How does this new thought feel compared to the original one?

Patient: It feels more balanced and less guilt-inducing. I can see how challenging the original thought and considering the evidence against it can lead to a more adaptive perspective.

Therapist: Exactly! This is the essence of cognitive restructuring – identifying negative automatic thoughts, examining the evidence for and against them, and reframing them in a more balanced way. As we practice this skill, it will become easier to catch and challenge these thoughts in the moment.

Now, let's discuss how you can apply this skill to setting boundaries with your family in the future. What are some steps you can take to assert your needs while still honoring your family values?

Patient: One step could be to communicate my needs and boundaries clearly and calmly, without apologizing or making excuses. I could also try to find a compromise when possible, like offering to help my sister on a different day that works better for me.

Therapist: Those are great ideas, Priya. Communicating assertively and finding compromises when possible can help you set boundaries while still maintaining positive relationships with your family. Remember that it's okay to start small and build up to more challenging boundary-setting situations over time.

As you practice setting boundaries, it will be important to continue challenging the negative thoughts that arise and reframing them in a more balanced way. This is where the Positive Data Log can be helpful – you can use it to gather evidence that supports your new, more adaptive beliefs about boundary-setting.

Patient: That makes sense. I can see how the Positive Data Log can help me build confidence in my ability to set boundaries over time.

Therapist: Absolutely! The more evidence you gather that supports your new beliefs, the easier it will become to challenge the old, negative ones. And as you set boundaries and see that the outcomes are generally positive, it will reinforce the idea that setting boundaries is healthy and necessary.

Before we move on, let's check in on how you're feeling about this discussion on boundary-setting. Has it brought up any other thoughts or emotions for you?

Patient: I'm feeling a mix of emotions. On one hand, I feel empowered and hopeful that I can make progress in this area. On the other hand, I'm still a bit anxious about putting these skills into practice, especially with my family.

Therapist: It's completely normal to feel a mix of emotions when discussing a challenging topic like boundary-setting. It's great that you're feeling empowered and hopeful, as those emotions can motivate you to keep practicing these skills. At the same time, it's okay to feel anxious about putting them into practice. Remember that it's a process, and it's okay to take small steps and go at your own pace.

As we continue to work on boundary-setting, we can explore any anxious thoughts that come up and challenge them using the same process we've been discussing. We can also brainstorm ways to manage the anxiety that feels manageable for you, like deep breathing exercises or positive self-talk.

Patient: That sounds helpful. I think I just need to remind myself that it's okay to start small and that I don't have to do everything perfectly right away.

Therapist: Absolutely, Priya. Boundary-setting is a skill that takes practice, and it's okay to start with smaller, less intimidating situations and work your way up to more challenging ones. Remember to be patient and compassionate with yourself throughout the process.

Now, let's shift gears a bit and discuss how your cultural background might be influencing your thoughts and behaviors around boundary-setting. Can you share a bit about how your culture views family obligations and boundary-setting?

Patient: In my culture, family obligations are taken very seriously. There's a strong emphasis on putting family first and being there for each other no matter what. Setting boundaries can be seen as selfish or disrespectful, especially when it comes to elder family members.

Therapist: That's a valuable insight, Priya. It's important for us to consider how these cultural values might be shaping your thoughts and behaviors around boundary-setting. It sounds like there could be a conflict between your cultural expectations and your personal needs for self-care and autonomy.

Let's explore this further. How do you think these cultural values might be reinforcing your core belief of "I'm not good enough"?

Patient: I think the expectation to always put family first reinforces the idea that my own needs and desires are less important. If I prioritize my own well-being over family obligations, it can feel like I'm not living up to the cultural ideal of a "good" family member.

Therapist: That makes a lot of sense, Priya. It's a common experience for people to feel torn between cultural expectations and personal needs. This conflict can exacerbate feelings of guilt and inadequacy, especially when there's a strong cultural value placed on self-sacrifice and putting others' needs first.

As we work on challenging your core belief of "I'm not good enough," it will be important to consider how your cultural background might be influencing this belief. We can explore ways to honor your cultural values while also recognizing the importance of self-care and boundary-setting.

One way to do this might be to reframe the concept of being a "good" family member. Instead of equating goodness with self-sacrifice, we could define it as being able to show up for your family in a way that's sustainable and authentic to you. This might mean setting boundaries when necessary so that you can be fully present and engaged when you are with your family.

What are your thoughts on this reframing, Priya?

Patient: I like the idea of reframing what it means to be a "good" family member. It takes some of the pressure off of always having to say yes and puts the focus on the quality of the time and energy I'm able to give. I think it will take some practice to internalize this new perspective, but it feels like a healthier way to approach family obligations.

Therapist: I'm glad this reframing resonates with you, Priya. It's a great first step in aligning your personal needs with your cultural values. As you practice this new way of thinking, it will start to feel more natural and automatic.

Another strategy we can use to challenge the cultural beliefs that reinforce your core belief is to examine the evidence for and against them. For example, let's take the belief that "Setting boundaries is selfish and disrespectful." What evidence do you have that supports this belief?

Patient: Well, I've seen other family members be judged or gossiped about for setting boundaries or prioritizing their own needs. There's definitely a cultural norm of putting family first, and people who deviate from that norm can face social consequences.

Therapist: That's a valid point, Priya. Social norms and judgments can be powerful reinforcers of cultural beliefs. Now, let's consider the evidence against this belief. Can you think of any examples of people in your culture who have set boundaries in a way that was respectful and well-received?

Patient: It's harder to think of examples, but I know there are some. My cousin recently set a boundary around not attending every family gathering due to her work schedule, and while there was some initial pushback, people eventually understood and respected her decision. It helped that she communicated her needs clearly and calmly, without being defensive or apologetic.

Therapist: That's a great example, Priya! It shows that setting boundaries can be done in a way that is culturally sensitive and respectful. It also highlights the importance of communication and delivery in how boundaries are received.

As we gather more examples like this, it can help build a case against the belief that setting boundaries is inherently selfish or disrespectful. We can use these examples to create a new, more balanced belief, such as "Setting boundaries can be done in a way that honors my cultural values and maintains positive family relationships."

What do you think about this new belief, Priya?

Patient: I think it's a healthier and more realistic belief to strive for. It acknowledges the cultural context while also leaving room for personal needs and self-care. I know it will take time and practice to fully internalize this new belief, but having concrete examples to draw on will help.

Therapist: Absolutely, Priya. Challenging long-held cultural beliefs is a process, and it's okay to take it one step at a time. We can continue to gather evidence and examples that support this new belief, and practice reframing situations that trigger the old belief.

As you work on setting boundaries within your cultural context, remember to be patient and compassionate with yourself. It's okay if it feels uncomfortable or if you face some pushback at first. With time and practice, it will become easier to assert your needs in a way that feels authentic and culturally sensitive.

What thoughts or questions do you have about applying this new belief to your own boundary-setting efforts?

Patient: I think my main question is how to handle pushback or resistance from family members regarding my boundaries. I know it's likely to happen, and I want to be prepared for how to respond in a way that's assertive but still respectful.

Therapist: That's a great question, Priya. It's very common to face some resistance when setting new boundaries, especially if it's a change from your usual pattern of behavior. Here are a few strategies you can use to handle pushback:

1. Stay calm and firm: When faced with resistance, it's important to remain calm and avoid getting defensive or apologetic. You can simply restate your boundary in a clear, firm manner. For example, "I understand you're disappointed, but I won't be able to help with the move this weekend."

2. Use "I" statements: Frame your boundary in terms of your own needs and feelings, rather than blaming or criticizing the other person. For example, "I need some time to recharge this weekend" rather than "You always demand too much of me."

3. Offer alternatives: If appropriate, you can suggest an alternative that works better for you. For example, "I can't help with the move this weekend, but I'm happy to help you unpack next week."

4. Validate their feelings: Acknowledge that the other person may feel disappointed or frustrated, but don't take responsibility for their emotions. For example, "I know you're disappointed, and I understand. But I need to prioritize my self-care right now."

Remember, it's okay if the other person is not happy with your boundary. The goal is to assert your needs in a way that's clear and respectful, not to control their reaction. With time and consistent boundary-setting, most people will adapt to the new dynamic.

What do you think about these strategies, Priya? Do you have any other questions or concerns about handling pushback?

Patient: These strategies make a lot of sense, and I appreciate the examples you provided. I think my main concern is dealing with the guilt and anxiety that comes up when I face resistance. Even if I know logically that I'm doing the right thing, it's hard to shake those feelings in the moment.

Therapist: That's a very common experience, Priya. It's normal to feel guilty or anxious when setting boundaries, especially if you're not used to doing so. Here are a few ways to manage those feelings:

1. Prepare in advance: Before setting a boundary, take some time to anticipate potential pushback and plan how you'll respond. Having a script or some key phrases in mind can help you feel more confident and less caught off guard.

2. Practice self-compassion: Remind yourself that it's okay to have needs and limits, and that setting boundaries is an act of self-care. Speak to yourself with kindness and understanding, rather than judgment.

3. Use coping statements: Develop some go-to phrases you can say to yourself when feeling guilty or anxious, such as "It's okay to prioritize my own well-being" or "Setting boundaries is not selfish, it's necessary."

4. Engage in self-care: After setting a difficult boundary, make sure to engage in some form of self-care to help manage any lingering stress or guilt. This could be anything from taking a walk to practicing deep breathing to treating yourself to a favorite activity.

Remember, the guilt and anxiety will likely decrease over time as you get more practice with boundary-setting. It's a skill that takes time to develop, so be patient and compassionate with yourself throughout the process.

What do you think about these strategies for managing guilt and anxiety, Priya?

Patient: I really appreciate these suggestions. I can see how preparing in advance and having some coping statements ready could help me feel more confident and less overwhelmed in the moment. And the reminder to practice self-compassion is always helpful.

Therapist: I'm glad these strategies resonate with you, Priya. Building a toolbox of coping skills can make boundary-setting feel more manageable and less emotionally taxing. Remember, you don't have to do it perfectly – the goal is simply to take small steps in asserting your needs and prioritizing your well-being.

As we wrap up today's session, let's take a moment to check in on your current mood and any final thoughts you have. How are you feeling after our discussion on boundary-setting and managing guilt and anxiety?

Patient: I'm feeling more hopeful and empowered than I was at the beginning of the session. Boundary-setting still feels daunting, but I have a better sense of how to approach it in a way that aligns with my values and takes care of my emotional needs. I know it will take practice, but I feel more equipped to handle the challenges that come up.

Therapist: It's great to hear that you're feeling more hopeful and empowered, Priya. Boundary-setting is a challenging skill to develop, but the fact that you're feeling more equipped and prepared is a sign of progress. Remember to take it one step at a time and celebrate the small victories along the way.

For homework this week, I'd like you to practice setting at least one boundary with a family member or friend. Use the strategies we discussed today, and pay attention to the thoughts and feelings that come up. You can use a thought record to challenge any negative thoughts that arise, and make sure to engage in some form of self-care afterward.

We can start our next session by discussing how the boundary-setting practice went and any insights or challenges that came up. We can also continue to explore the connection between your cultural values and your core beliefs, and practice reframing those beliefs in a more balanced way.

How does this homework and plan for our next session sound to you, Priya?

Patient: The homework sounds challenging but doable. I like the idea of starting with just one boundary and using the thought record to process the experience. And I'm definitely on board with continuing to explore the connection between my cultural values and core beliefs. I feel like we're making progress in that area.

Therapist: I'm glad the homework and plan for our next session feel manageable and relevant to you, Priya. It's great that you're open to continuing our exploration of cultural values and core beliefs – I think that work will be key in helping you develop a more balanced and compassionate relationship with yourself and others.

Before we end today, let me provide a summary of our session:

Session Summary:
- Main topics discussed:
  - Setting boundaries with family members and friends, particularly within the context of cultural expectations
  - Managing guilt and anxiety that may arise when setting boundaries
  - Continuing to explore the connection between cultural values and core beliefs

- Techniques or exercises used:
  - Thought records: Priya will use thought records to challenge negative thoughts that arise when setting boundaries for homework.
  - Positive Data Log: Priya will continue to gather evidence that supports new, more adaptive beliefs about boundary-setting and self-worth.
  - Cognitive restructuring: We practiced reframing the belief that "Setting boundaries is selfish and disrespectful" to a more balanced belief that "Setting boundaries can be done in a way that honors my cultural values and maintains positive family relationships."

- Homework assigned:
  - Practice setting at least one boundary with a family member or friend, using the strategies discussed in session
  - Complete a thought record on the boundary-setting experience, challenging any negative thoughts that arise
  - Engage in self-care after setting the boundary
  - Continue adding to the Positive Data Log, gathering evidence that supports new, more adaptive beliefs

- Patient's progress, challenges, depression symptoms and important personal details:
  - Priya is making progress in recognizing and challenging negative thoughts and core beliefs related to boundary-setting and self-worth
  - Priya's depression symptoms, such as feelings of guilt and anxiety, continue to be present but may be gradually improving as they practice CBT skills
  - Priya's cultural background and family relationships continue to be important factors in their therapeutic work

- Core beliefs and intermediate beliefs:
  - Core belief: "I'm not good enough"
  - Intermediate beliefs: "I should always be there for my family." "If I don't support my family perfectly, I'm a terrible sibling." "Setting boundaries is selfish and disrespectful."

- Important information to carry forward:
  - Priya's willingness to practice CBT skills and their recognition of the connection between cultural values and core beliefs are important strengths to build upon
  - Continuing to address cultural factors and family relationships will be crucial in understanding Priya's experiences and challenges
  - Tracking Priya's progress with thought records, reframing, and self-compassion will provide valuable information for future sessions

- Plan for the next session:
  - Review Priya's experience with setting a boundary for homework, discussing any insights or challenges that arose
  - Continue exploring and challenging negative core beliefs and cognitive distortions, particularly related to self-worth and boundary-setting
  - Introduce additional CBT techniques, such as cognitive and behavioral experiments, depending on Priya's needs and progress

Priya, thank you for your hard work and openness in today's session. I'm proud of the progress you're making, and I look forward to continuing our work together. Remember to be patient and compassionate with yourself as you practice these new skills. If any crises or emergencies come up before our next session, please reach out to the appropriate resources for support. Take care, and I'll see you next time.
